questions.text: Images of bone marrow aspiration(a) trephine biopsy(b) peripheral smear showing Gaucher's cell. Enzyme deficiency in the above condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glucocerebrosidase Gaucher’s disease It is a AR disorder and occurs due to deficiency of beta-glucocerebrosidase C/F: Bony pain, pathological fracture No MR (as beta-glucosylceramide is not present in brain) Hepatosplenomegaly present Large amounts of glucosylceramide accumulated in macrophages causing: Eccentric nucleus and Cytoplasm’s Crumpled tissue paper appearance or wrinkled appearance

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A. Glucose-6-phosphatase: Is deficient in Von Gierke disease (Ia),C/F includes glycogen accumulation in liver and renal tubule cells, hypoglycaemia, lactic academia, ketosis and hyperlipidemia. Option C. Hexosaminidase A and B deficiency causes Sandhoff’s disease with c/f: Neurological deficit and MR with cherry red spot. Option D. alpha galactosidase- Deficiency causes Fabry disease

questions.text: Intake of nutrients essential for maintaining normal health required by 97.5% of general population is known as?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Recommended dietary allowance The RDA is the average daily dietary intake level that meets the nutrient requirements of nearly all healthy persons of a specific sex, age, life stage, or physiologic condition (e.g., pregnancy or lactation)”. If someone takes less than 2 standard deviation of estimated average intake he/she is prone for deficiency. To ensure the optimum intake, extra allowance of 2 standard deviation is added to the recommendation

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option D. Dose allowance" typically refers to the maximum amount of exposure to a particular substance or radiation that a person can safely receive without experiencing harmful effects. The specific dose allowance will depend on the substance or radiation in question, as well as the individual's age, health status, and other factors.

questions.text: There is a history of village people consuming a crop as a staple diet. Many of the villagers are now presenting with paresis and are using a stick to stand. Which of the following vitamins would help?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vit C The villagers are suffering from Osteolathyrism which is a type of lathyrism that specifically affects bone health. It is caused by the consumption of the legume Lathyrus sativus, which contains a neurotoxin called beta-N-oxalyl-L-alpha,beta-diaminopropionic acid (BOAA). BOAA interferes with the cross-linking of collagen, a key structural protein in bone, leading to weakened bones and an increased risk of fractures. Osteolathyrism is most commonly seen in populations where grass pea is a staple food and is consumed in large amounts. The condition is characterized by a gradual onset of bone pain, muscle weakness, and difficulty walking. X-rays may show evidence of osteoporosis, bone deformities, and fractures. There is no known cure for osteolathyrism, and treatment is primarily focused on managing the symptoms and preventing further bone loss. Prevention of osteolathyrism involves limiting the consumption of grass pea and promoting a varied diet that includes other sources of protein and nutrients essential for bone health. Vitamin C acts as a cofactor for collagen hydroxylation which promotes crosslinking of collagen fibrils. Hence It can be used a prophylactic measure to manage the disease.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A. Vitamin A deficiency is most commonly seen populations where diets are low in animal products and vegetables. Option B. Vitamin D deficiency is caused in people with poor exposure to sunlight and in those who have a poor diet or malabsorption disorders. Option D. Vitamin K deficiency may be caused by prolonged antibiotic treatment which cause loss of intestinal microflora responsible for vitamin K synthesis in humans and in newborns due to a variety of reasons. Symptoms of vitamin K deficiency can include easy bruising, bleeding gums, and heavy menstrual bleeding.

questions.text: Diarrhea, dementia and dermatitis is caused by deficiency of
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Niacin Pellagra is a clinical condition due to the deficiency of Tryptophan as well as Niacin. Symptoms of pellagra: Dermatitis: In early stages, bright red erythema occurs in feet, ankles, and face. Increased pigmentation around the neck is known as Casal’s necklace. Diarrhea. Dementia, delirium, irritability, inability to concentrate and poor memory, ataxia, and spasticity are seen

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option D. Riboflavin deficiency: C/F are limited to skin and mucous membranes. It includes glossitis, magenta coloured tongue, cheilosis, angular stomatitis and circumcorneal congestion. Option B. Thiamine: Deficiency from excess of polished rice can cause beriberi and in chronic alcoholics c a u s e Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, which is characterized by loss of memory, lackadaisical behavior, and a continuous rhythmic movement of the eyeballs. Option A. Biotin deficiency includes dermatitis, atrophic glossitis, hyperesthesia, muscle pain, anorexia and hallucinations.

questions.text: Chronic alcoholic with features of ataxia confusion and 6th nerve involvement? Most commonly seen in deficiency of?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Thiamine Chronic alcoholics are at risk for thiamine deficiency, which play a role in the incoordination (ataxia) and psychosis that can become chronic (Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome). The thiamine deficiency produces relative deficiency of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option B. Riboflavin deficiency: C/F are limited to skin and mucous membranes. It includes glossitis, magenta coloured tongue, cheilosis, angular stomatitis and circumcorneal congestion. Option C. Niacin deficiency causes Pellagra, a condition associated with niacin deficiency, leads to diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia. Option D. Vitamin B12: deficiency symptoms include Megaloblastic anemia, Homocystinuria, Demyelination, Subacute combined degeneration and Achlorhydria.

questions.text: Baby with h/o raw egg ingestion. (picture of baby's scalp hairloss) deficiency of which vitamin?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Biotin Avidin, a protein present in egg white, which has great affinity towards biotin. Hence intake of raw (unboiled) eggs might cause biotin deficiency . Biotin is also known as anti-egg-white-injury-factor. As avidin is heat labile and boiling of egg will neutralize the inhibitory activity. One molecule of avidin can combine with four molecules of biotin. Egg white contains avidin and egg yolk contains biotin.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option (B, C, D): are not affected by avidin.

questions.text: Perioral rash, delayed wound healing is seen in deficiency of?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Copper Copper deficiency results in defective function of lysyl oxidase resulting in reduced crosslinkage of collagen. This will result in symptoms mentioned in this patient.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A. Selenium deficiency causes Keshan disease characterized by multifocal myocardial necrosis, cardiac arrythmias and cardiac enlargement. Option B. Zinc Deficiency is characterized by acrodermatitis (inflammation around mouth, nose, fingers, etc.), diarrhea, alopecia (loss of hair in discrete areas), ophthalmoplegia and hypogonadism.

questions.text: Diagnosis of black colour urine at birth.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Alkaptonuria Alkaptonuria is an inborn error of metabolism resulting from homogentisic acid oxidase deficiency, leading to the accumulation of homogentisic acid (HA), an intermediate in the catabolism of tyrosine. Manifestations include homogentisic aciduria (the urine contains elevated levels of HA, which is oxidized to a dark pigment on standing), arthritis, deposition of black pigment (ochronosis) in cartilage and collagenous tissue. Dietary restriction of phenylalanine and tyrosine will be helpful.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option B. Phenylketonuria: Deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase; C/F - mentally retardation, agitation, hyperactivity, tremors & convulsions due to interference of phenylalanine with neurotransmitter synthesis & hypopigmentation (inhibition of tyrosinase). Option C. Deficiency of the branched chain ketoacid dehydrogenase results in maple syrup urine disease which causes accumulation of branched chain ketoacids in blood, urine, and tissues. The urine has the maple syrup odor with development of metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: Child with cardiomegaly, pedal edema, cheliosis. What is the vitamin deficiency?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Riboflavin This patient's diagnosis is Riboflavin deficiency . Manifestations are confined to skin and mucous membranes such as Glossitis, Cheilosis, Magenta coloured tongue, Angular stomatitis (inflammation at the corners of mouth), Circumcorneal vascularization, Proliferation of the bulbar conjunctival capillaries is the earliest sign of riboflavin deficiency. INVESTIGATION: Riboflavin status is most commonly assessed by the glutathione reductase activity in freshly lysed red cells

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option C. Vitamin B6 deficiency: Peripheral neuritis, pellagra, microcytic hypochromic anemia, xanthurenic aciduria and homocystinuria.

questions.text: A child presented with difficulty in vision on examination cherry red spots were seen on macula. There was no organomegaly. Identify the disease.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tay-Sachs disease The symptoms are suggestive of Tay-Sachs disease, an autosomal recessive disorder involving neurodegeneration and early death. It is a sphingolipidoses or lipid storage disease, due to deficiency of the enzyme Hexosaminidase A. C/F: Mental retardation. Cherry red spot in the macula but No organomegaly. Progressive deterioration. Death by 3–4 years.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A. Gaucher’s disease is an AR disorder due to deficiency of beta-glucocerebrosidase. C/F: Bony pain, pathological fracture, No MR (as beta-glucosylceramide is not present in brain) . Hepatosplenomegaly present Option D. Niemann-Pick disease: C/F: Severe CNS damage, mental retardation, hepatosplenomegaly , Cherry red spot in macula. Death occurs by 2 years of age. Option B. Hunter Disease: It is a mucopolysaccharidosis without any cherry red spot on Macula

questions.text: A family consuming predominantly of polished rice would present with which of the following vitamin deficiencies? Match the vitamin deficiency with the investigation used to detect the deficiency.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Thiamine with Transketolase The Aleurone layer of cereals (whole wheat flour and unpolished hand pound rice) is rich in thiamine. When the grains are polished , the aleurone layer is usually removed causing thiamine deficiency. Thiamine Deficiency results in beriberi and in chronic alcoholics c a u s e Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, which is characterized by loss of memory, lackadaisical behavior, and a continuous rhythmic movement of the eyeballs. Also, Erythrocyte transketolase activity is reduced which is the earliest manifestation before the clinical manifestations

questions.text: A child was fatigued after exercise and the blood sample collected soon after exercise showed low glucose and lactate level. The probable diagnosis is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mc Ardles disease The given clinical case scenario pertains to Glycogen storage disorder Type V – McArdle's syndrome caused by defective muscle Glycogen Phosphorylase Type Name Enzyme Deficiency Clinical Features Ia Von Gierke disease Glucose-6 phosphatase Glycogen accumulation in liver and renal tubule cells; hypoglycaemia; lactic acidemia; ketosis; hyperlipemia VII Tarui disease Muscle and erythrocyte phosphofructokinase 1 Poor exercise tolerance; muscle glycogen abnormally high (2.5%-4%); blood lactate very low after exercise; also hemolytic anaemia IV Amylopectionosis, Andersen disease Branching enzyme Hepatosplenomegaly; accumulation of polysaccharide with few branch points; death from heart or liver failure before age 5 V Myophosphorylase deficiency, McArdle syndrome Muscle phosphorylase Poor exercise tolerance; muscle glycogen abnormally high (2.5%-4); blood lactate very low after exercise

questions.text: A 4-year-old child easy fatigability. The mother also complained that the child was more hungry between meals, and the child recovers after food. Liver examination revealed no glycogen?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glycogen synthase Easy fatigability and hunger between meals show defect in glycogen synthesis. No glycogen in liver indicate deficiency of glycogen synthase enzyme. The disease is called GSD type 0. The other clinical features are Hypoglycemia, hyperketonaemia; early death. Other Glycogen Storage Disease: Type Name Enzyme Deficiency Clinical Features IIIa Limit dextrinosis, Forbe or Cori disease Liver and muscle debranching enzyme Fasting hypoglycemia; hepatomegaly in infancy; accumulation of characteristic branched polysaccharide (limit dextrin); muscle weakness IIIb Limit dextrinosis Liver debranching enzyme As type IIIa, but no muscle weakness IV Amylopectionosis, Andersen disease Branching enzyme Hepatosplenomegaly; accumulation of polysaccharide with few branch points; death from heart or liver failure before age 5

questions.text: A person presented with neurological manifestations mimicking UMN palsy and sensory neuropathy. The patient was pale and investigations revealed anemia. The probable micronutrient deficiency is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vitamin B12 Causes of b12 deficiency: Gastric Atrophy, pregnancy, fish tapeworm, gastrectomy, malabsorption syndromes, nutritional deficiency, pernicious anemia. Deficiency manifestations: Demyelination, achlorhydria, folate trap, megaloblastic anemia, abnormal homocysteine level and homocystinuria, Subacute combined degeneration of the spinal Cord : Symmetrical paraesthesia of extremities, alterations of tendon and deep senses and reflexes, loss of position sense, unsteadiness in gait, positive Romberg’s sign (falling when eyes are closed) and positive Babinski’s sign (extensor plantar reflex).

questions.text: Respiratory distress syndrome is caused by the deficiency of?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lecithin Lecithin aka Dipalmitoyl phosphatidyl choline Lung surfactants are secreted by Type II pneumocytes. Surfactant reduces surface tension of the aqueous layer of lung and prevents collapse of lung alveoli. Constituents of surfactants: Dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine (DPPC) or dipalmitoyl lecithin (DPL), phosphatidyl glycerol, cholesterol and surfactant proteins A, B and C. During fetal life, lung synthesizes sphingomyelin before 28th week of GA & when fetus matures, more lecithin is produced. The lecithin-sphingomyelin (LS) ratio of amniotic fluid is an index of fetal maturity. If the ratio is 2, it indicates full lung maturity. Lecithin absence from the lungs of premature infants causes respiratory distress syndrome. Premature infants have a higher incidence of RDS because the immature lungs do not synthesize enough DPL.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A. Phosphatidyl ethanolamine or Cephalin is found in bio membranes and possess amphipathic properties. Option D. Cardiolipin or Di phosphatidylglycerol is a major lipid of mitochondrial membrane and extracted from myocardium. Decreased cardiolipin level results in mitochondrial dysfunction, heart failure, hypothyroidism, and myopathies.
